posts.author: MaaterOfNotAlot
posts.content:
Hey everyone!

I'm looking to join up on the Arelith server. I played there a year ago, but stopped due to getting occupied with other things. I didnt even play long. I believe my character was level 7 or so.

Anyway, I have always been horrible at building and preplanning builds for NWN. I just don't know where to begin when it comes to feats, skill allocation, when to level a certain class, etc.

I know I want to play a Halfling Rogue, with a bit of Monk for APR and bonus AC. I'll stick with dual wielding kamas. Possibly Fighter as well, though I'm open to an alternate third class. Really I have no intention of range weapons.

Playstyle would be your run of the mill Rogue: Opening locks, stealthing around, removing traps, setting traps to assist in combat(if its even viable, but I do like the idea of setting my own traps.)

The problem is, I have been told Discipline is a must have skill. None of the builds I've found contain it, so I'm not sure how to go about including it into a build.

I don't plan on using any of the server's subraces. I will however select the +2 DEX gift and possibly the +2 INT gift.

Arelith caps at level 30.

Classes must be taken 3 consecutive times before leveling into a new class.

EXAMPLE: Rogue would need to be at level 3 before being able to level into Monk; Monk at level 3 before leveling back into Rogue, or another class.


I'm just a newb when it comes to this. All of my googling and searching on builds has always brought me to these forums. So I figured, I'll come to the pros.

Thanks!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello there MaaterOfNotAlot - and welcome!

I've a couple of thoughts, a couple of questions and a couple of observations, if you don't mind?

So, if you're going for dual-wielding kamas, you'll need the 2-weapon fighting, ambidexterity and improved 2-weapon fighting feats (assuming you'll be trying for the maximum number of attacks per round - always helpful with a Dexterity-based build, which I'm assuming this is). The Fighter class would be useful in that regard because of the sheer volume of bonus feats it attracts. However, you could get them for free if you take 9 levels of Ranger (as long as you stay in robes or light armour, which I guess you'd be doing anyway, else you'd lose the Monk speed and AC among other things) so my first thought would be a Rogue/ Monk/ Ranger build with a minimum of either 10 levels of Rogue and 9 of Monk and Ranger: or 13 of Rogue, 6 of Monk and 9 of Ranger. Either of these will also enable you to get Epic Dodge - the Dexer's best friend. A third way, which would keep a lot of bonus feats and help with your saves would be the Champion of Torm prestige class, but I may be muddying the waters here.

So, what do you think about the Rogue/ Monk/ Ranger concept? We can start getting into the practicalities once we've sorted that out.

Oh, and does the taking of 3 consecutive levels in one class apply throughout the build, or just the first time you take the class?

Good to have you on board!

Cheers

posts.content:
Thanks for the response.

The leveling system is just for the first time you take that class, not throughout the entire build.

The ranger build does seem interesting. I even looked into adding ranger to mix things up a bit. Id probably go for the second option.

And yes, I would be staying in light armor.

Thanks

EDIT: I should also add, I will primarily be PvE, though I would like to remain viable in PvP if the situation were ever to occur.

When you dual-wield, the off-hand weapon needs to be one size smaller than you are, or you will lose 2 AB. For most races, the kama qualifies because it is small and they are medium, but for a Halfling (or Gnome) the kama is the same size category as they are (small). Only a tiny off-hand weapon will avoid that penalty. Arelith has a lot of customizations, so maybe they changed that for kamas, like they did for katanas for medium-sized races.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ah, thank you, but I suspect you're not going to like what comes next...

I've been bouncing a few permutations around, and with only 30 levels to play with things all got a bit cramped, and in my best-case scenario either Monk 6 (Knockdown/ Improved Knockdown) came ridiculously late, or Ranger 9 did (Improved 2-Weapon Fighting), or Epic Dodge got delayed to level 30. So I looked at dropping Monk down to 3 levels. Then I realized I could get improvements by dropping both Monk and Ranger and replace them with CoT. Specifically, a halfling Rogue 16/ CoT 14 build.

What CoT brings to the table (with 10 levels taken pre-epic) is enough bonus feats to cover the losses and bring more. Thus, rather than just the 7 general feats, you'd now have 5 more bonuses to play with, meaning you can take (in no particular order atm): Exotic Weapon Proficiency (so you can take kukris, for no AB penalty), Weapon Focus (in kukri, not surprisingly), Weapon Finesse, Ambidexterity, 2-weapon Fighting, Improved 2-weapon Fighting, Improved Critical (kukri), Blind Fighting, Knockdown, Improved Knockdown, Dodge and one other (maybe Toughness, Iron Will, Mobility or Stealthy). There's also a CoT bonus feat in epic levels, so you can get Epic Weapon Focus, Epic Dodge, Epic Prowess, Armor Skin and Great Dexterity 1. And, of course, with CoT you'll be getting a (much needed in some cases) boost of 7 to all your Saves.

By only using the two classes, and going for 16 levels of Rogue, you can also get Crippling Strike as the Rogue bonus feat at that level.

As for the skills, by my reckoning you'd have 279 to play with. That should be enough to max Tumble, Hide, Move Silently, UMD, Search, and either Spot or Listen. At the same time, there's still enough to get all you need in Disable and Set Trap, as well as Open Locks. After all that, you'll still have 24 points left. Now, there has been much debate over the years about whether Dex-based characters should bother with Discipline (there's a debate on that very subject in the General Discussions sub-forum here if you fancy a read). In this instance, I would be much more inclined to cross-class 12 points in Spellcraft (meaning, coincidentally, exactly the 24 points remaining) for a modified +3 save versus Spells.

I think this would be an improvement, but it's your build, so over to you...

Cheers

EDIT: Sorry, meant to mention, this was all based on starting stats (including taking gifts in Dex and Int) of STR 12, DEX 20, CON 14, WIS 10, INT 16, CHA 8, and finishing with 28 in DEX.

Where would Boo be without Minsc? It's like Tom without Jerry or Trump without Twitter.)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ha - indeed! Alas, I think it may throw us all off course if we keep exchanging Minsc quotes, as at least Valerfor and I did back in 2014/5 (though please come back with any we forgot - they're mostly in the Non-shooty, non-magcky elves build I requested back then). And I refer you to my strapline for my commitment to our Rasheman friend. There are many times I have taken - and will continue to take - Minsc over and above potentially "better" comrades, purely because he's, well, Minsc.

It's a shame in many respects than NwN doesn't have a comparable character. Maybe Deekin comes closest.

Oh hells, I can't resist it - "Look, Boo - squirrels! throw nuts, Boo, throw nuts!"
